awd_titl_txt: On the Trail of the Most Massive Galaxy Clusters in the Observable Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxy clusters are enormous reservoirs of galaxies, hot gas and mysterious "dark" matter.  The hot gas produces a signal at millimeter wavelengths.  The most massive clusters produce the strongest signals.  Such signals can be detected from clusters anywhere in the universe.  The team used millimeter observations from a space mission to identify massive cluster candidates.  They will obtain follow-up observations to confirm the cluster identifications.  The clusters will be used to test models of how structures form in the universe.  They will also be used to constrain cosmological parameters.  Senior team members will train junior team members.  The team will develop material in Spanish and present it in Spanish in Illinois schools.  The team will also engage with underrepresented minorities in South Africa.
 
The team will conduct follow-up observations of candidate galaxy clusters discovered through the Sunyaev-Zeldovich (SZ) effect.  Their extensive imaging and spectroscopy with ground-based facilities will yield confirmed clusters.  These are expected to be at high redshift and have high SZ-determined masses.  The team will use the clusters to (1) test the Lambda Cold Dark Matter model for structure formation in the universe and (2) improve constraints on cosmological parameters from galaxy cluster counts.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we studied galaxy clusters, the largest gravitationally organized structures in the universe that are signposts for the densest parts of the cosmic web.  Clusters are visible across the electromagnetic spectrum and can be seen using the X-ray emission from the cluster's hot gas, visible-band emission from cluster galaxies, radio emission from high energy electrons accelerated by cluster shocks, and most recently from measurements of the distortions to the cosmic microwave background imposed by the cluster's hot gas.  In the past decade measurements of these distortions (called the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich [SZ] effect after the astrophysical theorists who discovered it) have become fairly routine, thanks to the Planck satellite mission and two ground-based experiments: the South Pole Telescope and the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT).

In one of our key publications from this project we focused on the confirmation of galaxy cluster candidates from the high signal-to-noise end of the second all-sky Planck SZ catalog (PSZ2). The core of our observational design relied on the use of visible band imaging to confirm the SZ detections as real clusters and provide photometric redshifts using the multicolor information.  The imaging data were acquired at a number of observing runs between 2014 and 2017 at the Kitt Peak National Observatory 4 m Mayall telescope.  Our observing strategy consisted of targeted griz observations of individual candidates with total exposure times sufficient to detect the brightest cluster galaxy and associated member galaxies (the so-called red sequence) in a cluster at a redshift of 1. We developed a sophisticated software system that converted the raw data into mosaicked and stacked images, multi-color JPEGs, and catalogs of galaxies with accurate positions, calibrated photometry, and photometric redshift estimates.  Galaxy clusters were identified through a combination of the maxBCG algorithm and visual image inspection. Cluster candidates were considered to be confirmed if they contained a large population of galaxies with similar redshifts and were spatially coincident (within 6 arcmins) with the reported PSZ2 position. Of the 85 unconfirmed PSZ2 candidates observed, we found only fifteen corresponding galaxy clusters, twelve of which were previously unrecognized as counterparts. The clusters we found were between redshifts of 0.13 and 0.78. The low identification fraction (only 17.6% of the observed sample) was unexpected given the reported high significance of the PSZ2 candidates.  To explain this low identification fraction, we considered several possible scenarios: that the counterpart clusters were not confirmed because they were at low redshift, at high redshift, located in fields with high object density or because the Planck detection was distorted by radio source emission. None of these scenarios can account for the low purity of rich galaxy clusters among the high signal-to-noise PSZ2 unconfirmed candidates, indicating that the high significance of the Planck detections may be spurious in a number of cases.

The broader impacts of this project extended across education and training at all levels.  At the K-12 level Menanteau served on the leadership of Cena & Ciencias. At the undergraduate level Hughes served as a mentor to six undergraduate students who worked on aspects of this project and have had various outcomes in their careers to date, including attending law school, pursuing a degree in fashion design, and one currently applying for graduate school in astrophysics. Three of these students were participants in Project SUPER (Science for Undergraduates: A Program for Excellence in Research), a STEM-focused enrichment program through the Rutgers Douglass Residential College that offers undergraduate women the opportunity to actively participate in academic research.  Dr. Peter Doze obtained his PhD thanks in part to support from this program and is currently searching for a postdoctoral position. Dr. John Wu, worked with Dr. Boada on a machine learning study supported by this project, and is now employed at STScI, working on machine leaning and artificial intelligence applications to astronomical data.  Two post-doc or higher level researchers, Dr. Steven Boada and Dr. Aurelia Pascut, participated in work that produced refereed publications. Dr. Boada is now working in industry as a software/IT professional. Dr. Pascut is a professor at "Stefan cel Mare" University of Suceava, Romania.
